description.narrative: Climdev fund togehter with AU and UNECA
Climdev fund togehter with AU and UNECA

The ClimDev-Africa Special Fund (CDSF) is the investment instrument of the ClimDev-Africa Programme and supports the building of resilience to the impacts of climate change in Africa. Specifically, CDSF supports African institutions to implement activities in three result areas: 1) Widely available Climate information, packaging and dissemination; 2) Quality analysis for decision support and management practice; 3) Informed decision-making, awareness and advocacy. CDSF was at the onset of the programme considered "a flagship programme for Africa" within Climate and Environment due to the composition of the programme with UNECA(ACPC) on the policy level, the AUC (DREA) at the political level and AfDB (CDSF) as the financial arm of the programme. Sida has been supporting the ClimDev Special Fund (CDSF, administered by AfDB) since its inception in 2013. Both allocations and disbursements from the fund have been slower than anticipated but now the fund is adequately staffed and its administration is well integrated with AfDB's overall work on climate change. CDSF is recognized as an important instrument for promoting climate services and innovative climate adaptation action across the continent. The fund and its staff are also instrumental in driving the climate change agenda within AfDB and using the Bank’s convening power and mandate to influence actors across the continent. As of November 2018, the funding provided to CDSF by Sida (75 MSEK) has been allocated and there is strong demand for additional for both 2018 and 2019. This demand has led AfDB to request additional short-term support from Sida to allow for continued project support to the end of 2019. The Swedish funding would be allocated according to the operational principles of CDSF and the rules and regulations of the Bank. In its request for additional funding from Sida the Bank outlines three areas where these funds will be invested: · Enhance the capacity of river basin organizations to deliver climate, weather and water services· Develop climate information services with high-resolution data and deliver climate services in flood and drought prone ecosystems· Policy and partnerships for the delivery of climate information services linking climate centers with regional operations for disaster risk planning These areas are a subset of the areas of interventions as outlined by the instrument establishing CDSF and are in line with the current strategy for Regional development cooperation – specifically results on and two of support area one. Increasing Sida’s support to CDSF and continuing to engage with AfDB on matters related to climate change is seen as an opportunity to capitalize on the long term support to ClimDev and benefit from the capacity that has been developed within the Bank for the administration of the fund.

description.narrative: The African Development Bank (AfDB) submitted a narrative and financial report of the ClimDev Special Fund on August 8, 2019. The report covers the period from January 2019 to December 2019. The report was due by the 31st of March 2020. The delay in submitting the report is likely to be linked to the global slowdown in related to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the report is informative and provides adequate information on implementation of activites planned for 2019 as well as the progress that has been made as of December 31, 2019. The ClimDev Special Fund (CDSF) has made significant progress in building the capacities of continental, regional and national climate information centers/agencies. During the reporting period, capacity building activities were done through procurement of essential/advanced equipments for the centers and through trainings. The continental center that is benefiting from this contribution is the African Centre of Meteorological Application for Development (ACMAD). In addition the capacity of four regional Climate Centers has been built. These regional centers are: (i) the Agro Meteorology and Hydrology Regional Centre (AGRHYMET); (ii) the IGAD Climate Prediction and Application Centre (ICPAC), (iii) the Centre d’Application et de Prévision Climatologique de l’Afrique Central (CAPC-AC) and (iv) the Southern African Development Community Climate Service Centre (SADC-CSC). The key results of the SAWIDRA program in 2019 are summarized below. According to the report, these continental and regional centers are now able to provide improved regional weather prediction against the end-of-program target of 3. Moreover, 24 additional Hydromet Institutions can now develop downscaled climate projections with high-resolution data against an end-of-program target of 30. Details of Capacity building activities can be obtained from the attached report. During the reporting period, the Bank was actively communicating the capacity building work that is being done in terms of making climate and weather available for disaster risk reduction and climate adaptation. The annual report also presents a link to a featured story on how the work done by CDSF supported Cote d’Ivoire to be better prepared to respond to deadly foods in Abidjan. With the first phase of CDSF coming to an end in 2020, the report emphasises the need to focus on resource mobilization in 2020 for the second phase of the initiative. Now that significant progress has been made to build capacities of institutions providing climate and weather information, it is important to review how this enhanced capacity is being used regionally and at country level for better preparedness and climate adaptation. On the financial part: -In general, the financial report is clear. - The fund made a disbursement of close to USD 2 million in 2019. - No additional funding was secured in 2019. - With fund dwindling and the first phase coming to an end, the Bank is looking for ways of mobilizing additional resources. -Audit report was unqualified although it was submitted late (January 18, 2021).
